content.text: Describe two precautions that the student should take when measuring the length of the spring, to ensure an accurate reading. You may draw a diagram
On Fig. 1.2, measure the stretched length \(l\) of the spring
Calculate the extension \(e\) of the spring for a load of weight \(W = 2.0 \text{N}\)
Use the equation \(e = (l - l_0)\)
The student measures the length \(l_{0}\) of the spring without any load
A load of weight \(W = 2.0 \text{N}\) is suspended from the spring, as shown in Fig. 1.2
Fig. 1.2

parts.label: (c)

content.text: The 2.0 N load is removed from the spring
A load U is made of modelling clay wrapped on a wire hanger. Load U is suspended from the spring
The student measures the stretched length \(l_{\mathrm{U}}\) of the spring
cm
Calculate the extension \(e_{\mathrm{U}}\) of the spring with load U

content.text: The extension of a spring is directly proportional to the weight of the load
Use your values of \(W\) and \(e\) from **(b)(ii)** and your value of \(e_{\mathrm{U}}\) to determine the weight \(W_{\mathrm{U}}\) of load U
Show your working
\( W_{\mathrm{U}} \)  =

content.text: Load U is fully immersed in a beaker of water, as shown in Fig. 1.3
Suggest a possible source of inaccuracy in the determination of \(\rho\) in this experiment
The student plots a graph of load against extension for the spring, to show that the two quantities are directly proportional
State how his graph line shows that load and extension are directly proportional
A student investigates the behaviour of a spring, and then uses the spring to determine the density of modelling clay
The apparatus is shown in Fig. 1.1
On Fig. 2.1, draw a voltmeter connected to measure the potential difference (p.d.) across terminals P and Q.
The switch is closed. The student moves the crocodile clip on the resistance wire so that the potential difference \(V\) across terminals P and Q is 5.0V
She measures the current \(I\) for the cell and resistor in series
Read, and record in Table 2.1, the value of \(I\) shown on the meter in Fig. 2.2
The student repeats the procedure in **(b)** for values of \(V = 4.5 \text{V}\), \(4.0 \text{V}\), \(3.5 \text{V}\) and \(3.0 \text{V}\). Her readings are shown in Table 2.1
Plot a graph of \(I / \text{A}\) (y-axis) against \(V / V\) (x-axis). Start both axes at the origin (0,0)
The e.m.f. \(E\) of the cell is equal to the value of \(V\) when \(I = 0.0 \text{A}\)
Determine the value of \(E\) from the graph
Determine the gradient \(G\) of the graph. Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information
The value of \(\frac{1}{G}\) is numerically equal to the resistance \((r + R)\) where \(r\) is the resistance of the cell and \(R = 4.0 \Omega\)
Calculate the resistance \(r\) of the cell
Suggest how the experiment and graph could be improved to obtain a more accurate value for e.m.f. \(E\)
A student determines the electromotive force (e.m.f.) and resistance of a cell by using a resistance wire
She uses the circuit shown in Fig. 2.1
Draw a normal at point \(\mathbf{N}\), extending above \(\mathbf{AB}\). Label the upper end of the normal with the letter \(\mathbf{L}\)
Extend the normal downwards until it crosses line \(\mathbf{CD}\). Label the point at which it crosses \(\mathbf{CD}\) with the letter \(\mathbf{F}\)
The student draws line **EN** as shown in Fig. 3.1
On Fig. 3.1, measure the angle \(\theta_{1}\) between the lines **LN** and **EN**
The student places a transparent block **ABCD** near the centre of the ray-trace sheet, as indicated in Fig. 3.1
The student places two pins, \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\), on line **EN**, as shown in Fig. 3.1
Suggest whether the two pins are a suitable distance apart for accurate ray tracing
Explain your answer
statement
explanation
The student views the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) through the block

He places two pins, \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\), so that pins \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\), and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\), all appear exactly one behind the other
Draw a line through \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\), extending the line until it meets \(\mathbf{NF}\)
Label the point at which this line meets \(\mathbf{NF}\) with the letter \(\mathbf{G}\)
Label the point at which this line crosses \(\mathbf{CD}\) with the letter \(\mathbf{H}\)
Draw a line joining points \(\mathbf{N}\) and \(\mathbf{H}\)
Measure the length \(a\) of line \(\mathbf{NH}\)
Measure the length \(b\) of line \(\mathbf{GH}\)
Calculate a value \(n\) for the refractive index, using the equation \(n = \frac{a}{b}\)
Measure the angle \(\alpha\), where \(\alpha\) is the smaller angle between lines \(\mathbf{RK}\) and \(\mathbf{GH}\)
A student suggests that the angle \(\alpha\) should be equal to the difference between the angle \(\theta_{2}\) from (e) and the angle \(\theta_{1}\) from (a)(ii)
State whether your results support this suggestion. Justify your answer by reference to your results
statement
justification
The student repeats the above procedure for an angle \(\theta_{2} = 40^{\circ}\)

He places two pins, \(\mathsf{P}_5\) and \(\mathsf{P}_6\), so that pins \(\mathsf{P}_5\) and \(\mathsf{P}_6\), and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\), all appear exactly one behind the other
* Draw a line through pins \(\mathsf{P}_5\) and \(\mathsf{P}_6\). Extend the line until it meets \(\mathbf{GH}\)
* Label the point at which this line meets \(\mathbf{GH}\) with the letter \(\mathbf{K}\)
* Label the point at which this line crosses \(\mathbf{CD}\) with the letter \(\mathbf{R}\)
Suggest a precaution which should be taken to ensure accurate results in this type of experiment
Suggest why different students, all carrying out this experiment carefully, may not obtain identical results
A student investigates the refraction of light by a transparent block
He uses his results to determine a quantity known as the refractive index of the material of the block
The student's ray-trace sheet is shown full size in Fig. 3.1
A student investigates the factors affecting the deflection of a wooden strip clamped at one end
Plan an experiment which enables him to investigate how **one** factor affects the distance \(D\) that the free end of the wooden strip moves downwards when loads are placed on it
The apparatus available includes:
a variety of wooden strips which can be clamped as shown in Fig. 4.1
a set of masses with a hanger
In your plan, you should:
list any additional apparatus needed
state the key variables to be kept constant
explain briefly how to carry out the experiment, including how \(D\) is to be measured and any precautions that must be taken to ensure reliable results
draw a table, with column headings, to show how to display the readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)
explain how to use the readings to reach a conclusion
You may add to Fig. 4.1 or draw another diagram if it helps to explain your plan
